0.20.text:
So, today I want to talk about process,
my process, kind of how I got there...

5.32.text:
and how it's changed
over the last few years.

7.76.text:
In order to do so,
I want to kind of rewind back to 2009...

13.24.text:
and show you guys an excerpt
from a piece called "195".

21.16.text: When I was at Mills and kind of...

24.36.text:
figuring out for the first time really
the kind of music that I wanted to make -

27.52.text: I'd been making music for years,

29.28.text:
but it was the first time that things
started to make sense and to gel for me.

33.88.text:
And so I was doing
a lot of vocal processing

36.72.text:
and starting to work with Max
for the first time,

42.24.text:
I was reading a lot of Donna Haraway
and Catherine Hayles, and...

46.12.text:
around that time, at Mills
and in other kinds of programs,

50.40.text:
there was this discussion happening
around laptop music.

53.32.text:
So, whether or not it was embodied,
whether or not it was engaging...

57.60.text:
And it probably seems
really passé now in 2015,

61.32.text:
but it 2009 and was still,
this kind of like, hot debate...

64.36.text:
as to whether or not
the laptop was an instrument...

67.68.text: and how it should be used on stage.

69.88.text:
So, y'know, reading Haraway and Hayles
I was really trying to come to terms with

75.20.text:
what live laptop-music meant,
what laptop-music performance meant.

80.68.text:
And so, one of the first pieces I made,
was this "195".

85.20.text: And I'll just play a little excerpt here.

184.12.text: So around that time I was also...

187.20.text:
y'know, that was the kind of work that
I was doing within the institution

190.72.text: and then, outside of the academy

192.24.text:
I was also playing
in several different bands,

194.40.text:
one of which was called Body
with Mat Dryhurst,

197.80.text:
whose name
is gonna come up a lot in this talk.

201.12.text:
And so, we were playing, y'know,
kinda like, dirty acid-techno in clubs

207.32.text:
and I was trying out some of the same
Max patches in those situations,

212.64.text:
And, even then, I mean,
I know it seems crazy now,

215.24.text:
but even then,
having a laptop in a club...

218.72.text:
at least where I was in San Francisco,
was still really looked down upon,

221.72.text:
people were like
"why aren't you playing hardware?"...

225.48.text:
It was still this kind of struggle, so I felt
like I was having to defend myself,

229.92.text:
for the decisions that I was making
inside the academy...

232.88.text:
and then also on the weekends
when I was playing out for fun.

237.84.text:
But, all I was really doing was kind of
like, making the music I wanted to hear...

242.04.text:
and combine the elements
that I wanted to hear...

243.84.text:
and do it on the equipment or the
machine that I wanted to do it on.

248.24.text:
yeah, in the academy it was like I wasn't
allowed to play music with a pulse...

252.68.text: and I love music with a pulse, obviously.

255.20.text:
And then in the clubs
you'd be made fun of for using a laptop,

258.00.text:
so it just felt like this constant necessity
to defend my position on things.

264.72.text:
And around this time
is when I came up with...

269.20.text:
is actually the most
intimate instrument that we've ever seen

272.28.text:
because it's kind of mediating
all of our daily experiences,

275.60.text:
from Skype calls to emails
to all these things...

278.68.text:
and so I was trying to, kind of,
come to terms with

280.56.text: what that meant as an instrument.

284.08.text:
So a lot of the work that was happening
around this time

286.68.text: that went into my first album Movement...

288.92.text:
was actually like,
a really intimate investigation

292.08.text:
of this relationship
that I had with the machine.

298.12.text:
even though some of the sounds are
very abstracted, it was still, like a very

302.68.text:
intimate, and "soulful" kind of exploration
that I was doing in the studio.

308.36.text:
So I wanna play
an excerpt from Breathe.

348.60.text:
So a lot of the ideas that I was kind of
teasing out with '195' at my time in Mills

354.12.text:
a lot of that stuff went into the album
as a whole movement

357.48.text:
and it's kind of this weird collection
of experimental songs and dance songs,

363.84.text:
all kind of living
in this same environment,

367.08.text: which was really scary for me at first

368.96.text: I remember kind of like agonizing

371.28.text:
over whether or not to put movement on
movement or to put fade on movement,

375.48.text:
as I felt like they were these kind of
competing worlds.

378.48.text:
And it's funny, I keep going back to one
track on this record called Interlude,

385.52.text:
and it's kind of one of the tracks which
went under the radar

388.40.text:
and no one really wrote about,
no one really payed attention to...

390.96.text:
But I think it was kind of, for me, at the
forefront of my process at the time

396.20.text:
because it was, y'know,
it had heavy vocal processing,

399.72.text:
but it was also using the voice to kind of
trigger turning points in the track

404.04.text:
with these kind of like,
hard shift and cuts.

464.04.text:
So at the time, I was really excited to be
having this kind of 'public conversation'

468.20.text:
about all these ideas
I'd been fostering in the academy

471.68.text:
and I was really excited
to tell everyone about

473.52.text:
y'know, everything that I was thinking
about, everything that I was reading.

476.20.text:
And it was kind of like, thrown into
public discourse for the first time

479.32.text:
which is amazing and a huge opportunity,
but it was also kind of this like

483.88.text: huge slap in the face where it was like:

486.24.text:
"not everybody wants you to talk about
your music...

488.72.text:
not everybody want to hear about
everything that went behind it".

491.40.text:
"Not everybody has the same viewpoint
of music that you do".

495.68.text: So, I got kind of, a lot of push-back for...

502.00.text:
for taking kind of a
conceptual approach to music.

505.28.text:
And I also got a lot of push-back
for having an academic background.

509.52.text:
So that was kind of like a new thing for
me to think about

512.96.text: like, "why is there this blow back?"

516.84.text:
Because for me,
the academy is also my job:

519.04.text:
like, I'm a doctoral student at Stanford
and so,

521.80.text:
I have a side band and teach and it
pays my bills, and so I was like

525.24.text:
wow, how could people be angry at me
for having to have a job.

531.96.text:
But, I do understand this kind of, impulse
for people to say, y'know

535.24.text:
"let music speak for itself,
stop over-analyzing everything"

538.20.text:
"you're ruining it with your babble"
all this kinda stuff...

541.20.text:
and of course a lot of this kind of stuff
is just trolling online

543.52.text:
and you should never read YouTube
comments...

546.72.text:
But it did make me think about that,
kind of,

550.24.text:
conversation that we often have
in music press. How...

554.68.text:
How, kind of, conceptual music
can be demonized or we can kind of...

559.72.text: see it as something that's impure,

561.60.text:
or something that takes away
from the music itself.

565.32.text:
And that's something I've been thinking
about over the past couple of years.

569.52.text:
And, we've all been to concerts before
where there was like, some really boring

574.96.text:
abstract something
and then this huge program...

578.04.text:
that justified you sitting there for two
hours and having to watch something.

582.40.text:
And that's not what I'm talking about,
I think...

584.32.text:
I think that music should be
able to stand on it's own legs,

586.76.text:
and it should be able
to immediately touch people...

588.80.text:
but I don't think those things
are mutually exclusive.

593.80.text:
I think that you can have
ideas about your music,

596.12.text:
and you can have
something that's visceral,

600.92.text: For me, that's kind of like the Holy Grail.

608.48.text: So I started asking some questions.

612.44.text:
How can the concept of a work inform
the production of a piece

616.28.text: to the extent that it's actually audible?

618.92.text: So that one kind of main question,

620.28.text:
this is a question that sound artists
are grappling with all the time...

623.32.text: it's not necessarily new or unique to me.

626.92.text:
And how can we take ideas from extra
musical material or ideas

629.84.text:
and use that to generate
new aesthetics, new approaches,

632.84.text:
new production techniques that speak
to our lives today,

639.40.text:
And so that doesn't mean that all music
has to be conceptual to be good...

642.36.text:
It doesn't mean that all music
has to be made on a laptop.

645.00.text:
But that's just how I'm able to approach
music and can kind of...

649.16.text:
find purpose and find a meaning
to drive it forward.

653.08.text:
So, in terms of
approaching these questions,

657.28.text:
like, one really clear, low-hanging fruit
is obviously text and lyrics.

664.84.text:
So, I wanted to kind of...
yes, that's great...

668.96.text:
but I also wanted to figure out how
the production itself,

672.12.text:
the production techniques themselves,
could actually...

675.80.text:
be embodied with these ideas
that I was kind of working through.

679.04.text:
How that could actually be audible
in the production and the performance.

685.68.text:
So, the next piece that I was working on
was Chorus.

690.48.text:
and it was kind of inspired by this...
This is a screenshot of my laptop

695.76.text:
that I made for this.
This isn't a candid one, I staged this.

700.76.text:
But, this is familiar to everyone,
like a million pages open,

704.80.text:
doing a million things at once,
this kind of like...

708.40.text:
some people call it incoherence, or we
can think of it as like a 'new coherence'

711.84.text:
where everything is happening at once
and everything's flattened...

714.36.text:
and all on this window
that we have to the world.

718.04.text:
And so, my partner Mat Dryhurst
was working on some software

726.20.text:
that he made
some pieces with and presented

728.76.text: several years ago at the Guggenheim.

731.44.text:
And the idea behind the Net Concrète
system is that it kind of uses this...

737.24.text:
uses this approach of surveillance:
surveillance is self surveillance...

741.52.text:
so a lot of people use surveillance
for fitness programs if you wanna like,

745.80.text:
track how many steps you've taken or
how many calories or whatever.

748.72.text:
That's the term for surveying yourself,
so it's this idea of self surveillance,

754.04.text:
recording all of the audio that was kind
of funneling through the laptop...

758.56.text:
and then splicing that together to create
kind of like a new pallet.

764.20.text:
And so where as Musique concrète for
many of the pioneers

767.16.text:
was about kind of abstracting the sound
from the meaning, from the origins...

772.40.text:
this was more about kind of
bringing that back together,

777.04.text:
and acknowledging where those samples
where coming from...

780.36.text: and the familiarity of those sounds.

784.16.text:
I also treated the vocal production
in kind of a weird way.

788.96.text:
I don't know if you've heard the track,
I'll play a couple of clips...

793.16.text:
but I kind of like, chop off the attack
and decay, so it's this like "stuttered"...

798.32.text:
to kind of emulate like a Skype
conversation or y'know,

802.96.text:
like a non-seamless stream of audio
that you're receiving online.

808.12.text:
I then I decided to marry that
with the kick-drum

810.32.text:
which is also
not the "usual" production technique:

815.16.text: usually you'd wanna kind of like...

817.36.text:
snakily weave the vocal and the kick
throughout each other,

821.32.text:
but instead I wanted it to be this kind of
'kick' and like, smack in the face

825.12.text:
with the voice with this kind of like
'chopped off' voice for impact.

829.88.text:
Then I also used every kind of voice
I could get my hands on:

832.68.text:
vocals, tons of different processes of my
own voice, vocal samples

837.48.text: to create this kind of like "digital choir"...

842.28.text: as kind of like the backing vocalists.

846.44.text:
And what I was really trying to do
is capture the sound of the internet

849.28.text:
that, yes, does involve kitsch
and yes, does involve jingles

852.48.text:
but also is like a really terrifying place
and a really emotional place.

857.32.text:
So I wanted to kind of - not flatten -
an internet aesthetic...

864.84.text: Let's see if I can play the right...

881.40.text:
I'm gonna turn the volume
off for a second...

882.72.text: because some of these early clips...

886.80.text:
there's me laying
on the floor with a chair...

889.00.text: I don't know if that already passed...

890.84.text: But that was... Mat was away on...

894.16.text:
on a work trip...
and we were talking on Skype and I...

897.12.text:
You know when you have those really
long Skype sessions...

899.20.text:
that start to go for like, an hour, and then
you just start doing a really weird thing...

902.36.text:
I was just playing with a chair in the
living room and he was...

906.72.text:
So there was a lot of this kind of
personal, intimate stuff added in as well

911.28.text:
and you can see Akihiko's desktops,
so kind of, bringing in the mundane

916.12.text:
but the really hyper-personal
about these work spaces

919.44.text: and these work stations that we use.

921.56.text:
These are the places...
we're spying on people's work places,

925.76.text:
we're spying on people's
intimate spaces

927.88.text:
where they're spying on the world
through their devices.

932.20.text: So I'll play a little excerpt.

941.72.text:
I should also mention, the video is made
by Mat Dryhurst and Akihiko Taniguchi.

946.36.text: Akihiko is an amazing visual artist who...

950.40.text:
He uses the photo-synth app and then
kind of 're-synthesizes' these 3D worlds

957.60.text:
that then you can kind of navigate
a Machinima-style drive through.

1022.24.text:
OK, I'm gonna go on...
And that's really fun to play.

1032.32.text:
That's really fun to play now that
Colin Self, who's sitting in the audience,

1038.40.text:
and who can hit some of those notes
a lot better than I can live.

1043.36.text:
So, this brings me to Home, which was
the next single that I released.

1048.20.text: And this was kinda where I was

1050.20.text:
y'know going back over texts that I'd
kinda put over here to rest for a minute

1055.16.text: like, wanted to pull it back in.

1056.32.text:
I've always felt really weird
about writing lyrics,

1059.20.text:
it's never really been
a strong suit of mine...

1061.00.text:
so I was like, OK, I'm gonna try to write
like a "songy song" with lyrics

1064.64.text:
and I'm gonna try to marry that
with production techniques

1067.20.text:
and see if I can have it all kind of live
in the same world together.

1072.00.text:
So... the way that
piece kinda started is, I was...

1075.72.text:
teaching during the week and then I was
touring on the weekends...

1078.52.text:
and at that time I didn't have
international roaming on my phone

1081.68.text:
so I was like, y'know... grading papers
on the plane going playing a show...

1086.84.text:
then hopping back on a plane and like
running from hotspot to hotspot

1091.88.text:
and I felt like my inbox was more like
my personal home, my private zone

1096.92.text:
than even my San Francisco apartment
cos' I was rarely there.

1100.44.text:
So I started kind of questioning
what that meant,

1103.56.text:
if that was actually my intimate home,
and then in light of Edward Snowden's...

1110.84.text:
y'know, that became
like a really sinister reality.

1114.64.text: If that wasn't actually a private space.

1118.56.text:
So it kind of turned into a betrayal song,
or break-up song, love song

1123.36.text:
with the NSA agent
who was spying on me.

1125.96.text:
Who, if they weren't spying on me,
then is definitely spying on me now.

1131.60.text:
So, y'know, some of the lyrics are:
"I can feel you in my room"

1136.84.text:
"I know you know me
better than I know me"...

1139.08.text:
I this kind of also harkens back to the
laptop as the most intimate instrument.

1144.60.text:
Because in some ways
I do feel like the laptop

1146.56.text:
does know me and know my habits and
knows things about me

1149.80.text: that I don't wanna admit to myself, like...

1151.84.text:
knows exactly how many hours
I'm streaming television,

1154.52.text:
even though I might say I'm watching so
many hours a week,

1159.84.text:
Yeah, so I was kind of investigating
that a little bit.

1163.44.text:
So again, I was using Mat's Surveillance
- Net Concrete patch again...

1168.64.text: to create some of the sound design.

1172.04.text:
There's some recordings on there again
that he like, sneakily recorded

1176.52.text:
during conversations that we were
having on the phone

1178.68.text:
or on Skype, there's like a laugh in there
that when I hear

1182.00.text:
it still kind of like makes the hairs stand
on... on my...

1186.52.text:
the hairs stand on...
I don't know how that phrase goes.

1189.36.text: Anyways, it makes my hairs stand.

1191.32.text:
Because I hear it and I'm like, oh my
God, that was such an intimate moment

1194.20.text:
it wasn't like giggling in the mike
in the studio, it was like this...

1198.44.text:
this really intimate moment,
so when I hear that in a public space

1201.16.text:
it still kind of is like slightly jolting
and that was the point of the piece,

1204.00.text:
I wanted to make something that would
make me feel uncomfortable.

1207.08.text:
So, it's also the song with the least
amount of processing on my voice...

1212.96.text:
Kind of like showing
a naked voice a little bit.

1215.40.text: And also it was the first time that...

1217.60.text:
I ever was lip-singing for a video,
I dunno, I felt really conflicted about it,

1222.56.text:
I felt really cheesy singing along
so I only did two takes,

1226.92.text: We recorded it in a friend's studio

1229.72.text:
with like no make-up or hair team
or anything like that.

1232.96.text:
But it was really important
that it kind of captured

1238.60.text:
It wasn't just the production technique
or the lyrics, but it's also

1242.20.text:
the approach of the video and I wanted
everything, the performance of it...

1246.60.text:
I wanted it all to be like this holistic thing
that was about the topic itself.

1252.80.text: Let's see if I missed anything.

1308.56.text: So I'm gonna stop it there.

1309.68.text:
So Metahaven came up with the idea to
take the logos

1313.12.text:
that were released that the NSA was
actually using for some of their...

1316.12.text:
covert programs
and they had a dear intern cut out

1322.28.text:
so that they could create this kind of like
data-rain with all of these logos.

1327.48.text:
Which I thought was so visually
compelling

1331.28.text:
So that was the first time that we had
the opportunity to work with them,

1334.36.text:
and I'm gonna jump back to them
in a second, but that kind of like...

1338.72.text:
I don't know if you heard that kind of
"monster rumbling"...

1342.44.text: 'from one side to the other' sound...

1344.64.text:
That actually came out of...
or the way to make that

1348.20.text: came out of a project that Mat and I did

1350.48.text:
in a gallery called Sommer & Kohl
in Berlin.

1354.12.text:
So they had an exhibition called
Rain, Steam and Speed...

1357.12.text:
which was based on a famous Turner
painting

1359.92.text:
And they asked us to do a sound
installation, that...

1362.72.text:
I don't know if you can see the little,
white speakers in there -

1364.68.text:
it's always so hard to show a sound
installation

1370.52.text:
So we were installing this
from California and were both like...

1373.44.text:
"argh, it's like terrifying
to install something from abroad."

1376.52.text:
But we decided to use a mp-sonic
set-up with the four speakers.

1381.16.text:
And we wanted to have
these kind of like little...

1385.96.text:
run across the gallery
every 30 seconds or so,

1389.56.text:
irregularly that would just kinda be like
"what was that?"...

1392.24.text:
And I don't know how much experience
you guys have with mp sonics, but...

1396.12.text:
with four speakers it's not perfect but
you can still get this feeling

1399.88.text:
or something kind of like,
running though the room

1401.76.text:
instead of it just being kind of like
spacialized on the edge.

1405.60.text:
So yeah, we created this process
of how to get these,

1408.76.text:
little, caged-sounding animals
kind of running across the room.

1411.40.text:
I'm gonna play a couple of examples
from the exhibition.

1425.68.text:
So that's like a mixture of foley
and synthesis, put through this process,

1431.56.text:
but for home, I recorded myself
running around karma,

1437.52.text:
I don't know, like a weird creature
with like, ten legs and three arms, like...

1441.40.text:
struggling to like, y'know rush across
the room in this monsterly kind of way.

1450.16.text:
Home was the first video
that we worked on together,

1453.16.text:
and around that time we decided that
we wanted to work on Platform together,

1460.12.text:
One of the reasons why I was drawn
to Metahaven is because they...

1464.88.text:
They've been really successful at
building in their conceptual framework

1469.76.text:
into the aesthetics, into the new
aesthetics that they create in their work.

1473.44.text:
So it was hugely inspiring at how
kind of, holistic their practice was.

1477.52.text:
And I was also really drawn to their
ability to kind of seamlessly draw...

1481.52.text:
their political interests into their work
without making it too didactic or too dry.

1485.80.text:
They're especially good at bringing in
kind of an emotional aspect, I think...

1494.24.text:
all of the music I've made has been
from an emotional place.

1497.84.text:
I think sometimes I would bury
the emotion under some layers, y'know...

1504.00.text:
so that you'd have to peel back
and discover it, but...

1506.80.text:
they have a way of being overt
about their emotions in a way

1512.36.text: that doesn't come across as tacky or...

1519.76.text:
So I was really drawn to their ability
to be so direct with their emotions.

1526.76.text:
This is a scarf they made to fund raise
for Wikileaks.

1531.76.text:
when the banking institutions cut off
the money to the organization.

1535.48.text:
I love how it's obviously talking
about transparency...

1539.40.text:
but they also have such a
visual language that's unique to them...

1542.40.text:
that also speaks directly
to what they care about.

1548.68.text:
Platform. So we decided to work
on platform together, with Mat as well.

1555.24.text:
And for Platform, there were like a million
ideas being banded around...

1560.00.text:
but one of the main ideas
was Pop as a carrier signal.

1564.36.text:
So, I've been thinking about, y'know...
lyrics, production techniques,

1569.08.text:
performance. All these things going
into the concept behind the work,

1573.72.text:
and so I started to wonder if that could
kind of like, spread out from there

1577.84.text:
and start to infect other aspects
of the music-making process.

1581.56.text:
So, one of the biggest things in the
music-making process

1583.88.text:
is your album release and this whole
hoopla around it and all of the press,

1589.88.text:
and everything and so I was like, we
were all kind of questioning, you know,

1593.64.text:
what are some different things
that we can do with that.

1596.32.text: So one thing I wanna talk about is...

1601.24.text:
snippet, like this isn't everyone,
but this is like...

1603.64.text:
a list of people whose ideas
and thoughts and message and love

1609.40.text:
And that was kind of one of the main
things I wanted to think about, is...

1612.68.text:
we have this habit, especially in
electronic music, of liking to think of this

1617.56.text:
lone genius, lone-like Guru on a
mountain somewhere, like channeling...

1623.68.text:
you know, channeling ideas and creating
all of this amazing work.

1627.52.text:
And of course, there are amazing
individuals doing amazing work, but...

1630.48.text:
I feel like ideas come
from a community of people.

1634.88.text:
Y'know, a lot of the stuff that I do is
directly impacted by different decisions

1639.92.text:
that engineers at Max-MSP are making
or engineers at Ableton.

1645.24.text:
Or, you know...
Authors that I'm reading at the time.

1649.12.text:
So all of these things are kind of like
funneled into this community,

1652.76.text:
and that's how these works are made,
and that's...

1655.28.text:
they don't just kind of...
or at least that's my experience,

1658.20.text:
they don't just, kind of like,
pop out of a vacuum or a void.

1663.32.text:
So we wanted to try to take
the opportunity of the...

1666.80.text:
of the press interest around the album to
talk about some of the philosophers,

1672.16.text:
and some of the authors and artists
who inspired a lot of the work,

1676.56.text:
and that I worked with
on a lot of the pieces.

1680.84.text:
So one of those pieces is
Lonely At The Top, that I made with..

1686.08.text:
Claire Tolan - she's an amazing artist
and developer and also...

1690.76.text:
and also has a ASMR radio show on
Berlin Community Radio.

1694.92.text:
So we were thinking about,
well obviously, digital intimacy...

1698.80.text:
embedding physical music
with a political message,

1701.04.text:
we thought could be
an interesting new twist.

1704.72.text:
So really it was thought of a ASMR for
the one percent.

1708.36.text: which is kind of like a...

1710.04.text:
I don't know if I'm allowed to
call myself bold

1711.60.text:
But it's kind of a bold move to put that
at the heart of the album, y'know...

1717.12.text:
the very center of an album to put in this
like, five minute, spoken-word

1721.20.text: kind of like, weird, ASMR piece.

1723.24.text:
But I thought it was a really important
piece to put in there because...

1728.08.text:
yes, it was speaking to one percent, but
it was also kind of speaking

1730.52.text:
to how we're all guilty of this...
the same thing, kind of like...

1734.48.text:
making excuses for ourselves and telling
ourselves that we deserve everything

1738.36.text: that we've been given, things like that.

1743.44.text:
This one was really inspired a lot by
Joe Meek, who was...

1748.12.text:
he was a production pioneer, he wrote
"I Hear A New World"

1754.32.text:
He came up with all kinds of new
production techniques.

1757.92.text:
He was marginalized for his sexuality
and had a really tough life.

1762.44.text:
But he was really able to imagine this
kind of like, other world, this new world...

1767.24.text: as early as the 1960s, kind of...

1769.88.text:
creating sounds that sound
hyper-contemporary today.

1773.88.text:
It's also kind of a love song
to digital activism...

1777.44.text:
<i>"In the seed where we live</i>
<i>always on"...</i>

And we also wanted to take the
opportunity to have the video be kind of

1784.04.text:
super-embedded in the piece,
so they kind of...

1787.00.text:
one doesn't really live
without the other, so...

1789.52.text:
instead of just having lyrics
live in the song,

1792.00.text: the lyrics kind of continue in the video.

1796.48.text:
we wrote a continuation of the lyrics
as a kind of manifesto...

We were also thinking about the spaces
where we...

enjoy art and music together
and so those little ad-banners...

we're thinking, y'know,
we're kind of questioning:

1816.84.text:
is this how we want to experience the
work of our peers,

1819.64.text:
and the work that we love with constant

but there's also tons of extra lyrics

A Declaration
of the Independence of Cyberspace

and it's also a quote from that text,

1884.04.text:
y'know, it's a very Utopian and idealistic

1889.08.text:
But I really liked the positive and Utopian
aspects of it and...

1896.80.text: in a way, positing this question, like...

1899.52.text:
do we wanna just accept
the way that things are...

1901.48.text:
or do we wanna try to fight to make
the world a place that we wanna inhabit.

1906.28.text:
Do we wanna just like throw up our
hands, that this is the way things are

1909.84.text:
or do we wanna be optimistic

1913.56.text:
Which is like really kind of like

1919.16.text:
OK, so this is a piece that I wrote,
I know you can't see anything right now,

1923.28.text: I'll play it in a second....

1924.40.text:
called Writer's Block. I was having
trouble writing, I was supposes to write...

1927.72.text: for a... solo percussionist for Stanford.

1931.88.text:
And I was really struggling with trying to
figure out how to make sense

1935.16.text:
of these acoustic instruments
at my practice.

1937.60.text:
It's not that I don't love
acoustic instruments,

1939.68.text:
I do love acoustic instruments but I was
trying to make sense of like...

1942.20.text:
I didn't wanna just add to the canon
of something that, in a way that,

1945.04.text: didn't make sense to what I was doing,

1946.44.text:
so I was really bashing my head
against my computer...

1951.16.text:
And so I ended up writing it about
this writer's block that I was having...

1954.60.text:
and so I decided to have it
for percussionist with laptop,

2006.84.text:
So he was physically playing the laptop,
like,creating a filter...

2010.84.text:
by covering the different speakers
and different frequency ranges

2014.36.text:
that were coming out of
the left and right speakers.

2017.40.text:
He was, y'know...
modulating the amplitude by his...

2020.84.text:
the distance between the microphone
and the speaker.

2025.44.text:
So I was trying to kind of like, turn the
physical laptop into an instrument again.

2030.40.text:
And I've done this in the past with...
Induction microphones.

2034.84.text:
It's a technique that I learned from
Scott Arford who's a Bay area...

2038.80.text:
media artist and musician. And he used
to attach them to TV monitors,

2044.48.text:
and then create feedback-loops
that he would play.

2046.28.text: So I use that sometimes and I'll map...

2053.76.text:
I'll map that to various parameters on my

2058.68.text:
gate or something like that,
so just like kind of trying to...

2066.20.text: And this brings me to my last slide.

2068.32.text:

2073.36.text:
and it was called
Everywhere and Nowhere.

2078.36.text:
So again in terms of the production

2086.12.text:
we went to this amazing festival
in Kutna Hora called Creepy Teepee.

2090.48.text:
And it's this really amazing
anti-fascist festival...

2094.88.text:
The aesthetic of the festival
is really interesting

2096.52.text: cos' it has this net-art aesthetic.

2098.92.text:
But it's very much filtered through
an Eastern European perspective.

2104.36.text:
And also there's a kind of immediacy
there that I don't necessarily always

2108.48.text:
always recognize in the West
because a lot of these kids were kind of

2111.32.text:
on a daily basis,
dealing with actual Nazis,

2114.08.text:
or were dealing with homophobes
all the time, so...

2116.84.text:
It was interesting to see this kind of like
urgency and agency

2119.76.text:
associated with this aesthetic that's
often been associated with...

2126.88.text:
So we kind of went back
to the ASMR idea and thought:

2130.80.text:
what if you could actually infuse...
infuse speech with ASMR tingles

2136.96.text: so we found a way to kind of like,

2139.40.text:
make the voice speak though different
ASMR foley sounds.

2143.48.text:
And then that was on a 24.1
surround sound dome,

2148.36.text:
that was developed at ZKM
and using their Zirkonium software.

2153.00.text:
I guess what I was trying to cover today
is that...

2156.72.text:
regardless of whether I'm
installing something in a museum,

2159.44.text:
or doing something in the academy
or writing a pop song,

2163.32.text:
I feel like I try to take the same approach
to all of those; I'm trying to...

2168.04.text: question every aspect of the practice,

2170.00.text:
I'm trying to experiment
with different aspects,

2172.48.text:
and I'm trying to make it conceptually
sound as a whole.

2174.88.text:
That doesn't mean that I'm reinventing
everything, every time.

2178.12.text: Or that I'm not drawing on a long lineage

2180.16.text:
in a long canon
of electronic music history.

2182.92.text:
But I'm trying to somehow
make it my own...

2185.04.text:
and make it very situated
in the time and place that I am today.
